 The claim that God does not exist is among the set of
 unprovable propositions that keep the logic choppers
 in business. 
 I don't think we can go further than saying that 
 "I don't believe in God because there's no evidence 
 for this supernatural agency that a reasonable
 person would recognise as such". 
 I know this leaves open the questions of what is meant 
 by "evidence" and what is meant by "reasonable" etc.
 But I have no problem with accepting the meanings of
 these terms that can be consulted in a dictionary.

 -Mach

 if aoiahoagh relates to a definable entity, then proof of its existence (or non-existence) can be found. if aoiahoagh is defined as "meaningless letters" then it does exist. if it is defined as something that doesnt exist in the first place, then it doesnt exist. the word "God" doesnt correspond to "meaningless letters" or "something that doesnt exist". when we use that word in english, we refer to a benevolent all-powerful supernatural deity. there is a difference
 
 the first step to determining existence is determining definition
 
 mach, do you think its possible we could all come up with a working definition of God that everybody involved could agree with?
Mach

if aoiahoagh relates to a definable entity, then proof of its existence (or non-existence) can be found. if aoiahoagh is defined as "meaningless letters" then it does exist. if it is defined as something that doesnt exist in the first place, then it doesnt exist. the word "God" doesnt correspond to "meaningless letters" or "something that doesnt exist". when we use that word in english, we refer to a benevolent all-powerful supernatural deity. there is a difference
 
 the first step to determining existence is determining definition
 
 mach, do you think its possible we could all come up with a working definition of God that everybody involved could agree with?

 
 Unfortunately not. This subject, unlike politics, healthcare, etc., isn't about opinon, it's about reality.
 
 No defintion I can conceive of, that's rational, would be anything close to the Christian definition of a god. But we have words for everything that we need words for (by in large).
 
 So yes, if we define god as something entirely possible, that could, within the bounds of reason, exist and not be self-contradictory, then we could. But then, we wouldn't be defining god, and we likely already have a good word for it. Another being that isn't from earth? We call that an alien, or more appropriately, an extra-terrestrial. 
 
 And yes, we do look for those. Indeed there still CAN have been an extra-terrestrial life form that sparked our creation, but entirely through physical processes, and who's own creation was most likely random, either case, we don't avoid reality. Would that qualify as god? Maybe, but again, we'd just as soon call it E.T.
 
 What about everything? We call that the universe.
 
 What about that which is omniscient and omnipotent? We call that self-contradictory...which is invariably what god is reduced to :/ That, or some rational definition which would not qualifiy as god.
 
 I would love there to be a kind, caring god looking out for us humans, but since he's on an indefinite lunch break, I'm content to help myself, and my fellow man, and not wait for him to finish eating his celestial soup and galactic crackers.
 
 The idea of a super-being inside our universe, one that has actually tinkered, through purely physical means, with our earth, is entirely possible, although there is no evidence to support it, and certainly no reason it would need to be so (Occam's razor). It also wouldn't fit the common definitions of God, so again, it really would just be "another life form", granted, maybe the first and singularly most powerful/intelligent, but call it what you will. I'd call it E.T.
 
 -Mach

Unfortunately not. This subject, unlike politics, healthcare, etc., isn't about opinon, it's about reality.
 
 No defintion I can conceive of, that's rational, would be anything close to the Christian definition of a god. But we have words for everything that we need words for (by in large).

 Here's my 2 cent's worth:
 No matter how carefully you refine your definition of God, what's the use of
 it, if he doesn't exist ? It would be possible, I suppose, to agree eventually
 on the definition of a centaur or a unicorn but our knowledge of reality 
 would hardly be the better for it. The only purpose I can see in "arriving at
 a definition of God" that will satisfy everyone, is perhaps in the practice of 
 semantic skills - a kind of solemn mental exercise.

Tastyfish

Thats not how you would set out to prove something or at least discover something - surely it would make more sense to look for reliable, preferably repeatable evidence that points to the existance of God and can not be explained by other means. Normally if you were going to look to see if there is an unknown substance involved in a reaction you would set it up with just the known parts, if it works as normal then you wouldn't expect to find anything else involved unless later evidence points to somethings involvment.
 
 Things like the effects of prayer against a placebo equivalent, regular miracles within the modern age or some other sign of worthwhile divine intervention (not just 'perhaps it would be a good idea to stop being an alcoholic). The fact that most divine visions, even those mentioned in the Bible and other holy books resemble temperal lobe epilepsy to a very strong degree. 
 
 Trying to define something that may or may not exist is a stupid way of trying to see if it exists, just try it with vampires. Something that is entirely down to individual interpretation is not going to defined down to a set of testable hypothesis.
 
 However I am curious how the ontological prrof works - looks like its saying that if god exists then he does (going from the short version), it doesn't seem to take into account the fact the 'greatest possible' (i.e being able to do anything that is possible) being might not actually exist. More so it seems to go completely against determinism where even the 'greatest possible being' would boil down to just anything, seeing as everything takes only the one possible action, or even that modified with quantum so that everything does everything that is possible? Without taking into account these how can it be valid?

While they may well be some wierd cosmic entity that created the universe we may find evidence of in the far future (via vaccum state tampering or when we work out how to do it ourselves) as far as the question in this thread with the chrisitian god goes the answer will be no, it isn't true.

Dzeron

Can science prove the existence of a Demonically Posessed Clock in the Parallel Universe?
 
 By definition, this evil chronograph is in another universe, not ours.
 
 Similarly, God, by definition, lives in Heaven, which is another universe.
 
 Science can only prove things about our universe.
 
 Furthermore, anything outside of this universe does not affect this universe. The universe runs on the laws of physics. Even if, as some say, God is the driving force behind the laws of physics, what is important is to pay attention to the laws themselves.
 
 Science cannot prove or disprove the existence of God. Nor does it need to. Nor does it intend to. The focus of science is on this universe and the things in it.
